Hey friends!
Let’s bring everything together.
Mars’s atmosphere is mostly CO₂ (95%), with tiny amounts of methane and other gases. • CO₂ is stable and cycles with the seasons (forms dry ice at poles, then returns as gas).
• Methane (CH₄) is rare and breaks down quickly, so sudden spikes suggest something active is happening.
• On Earth, scientists monitor gases above volcanoes to predict activity. Similar methods on Mars could reveal volcanic or subsurface processes.
• That’s why methane is so important—it could mean geological activity or even signs of life.
